data.title: Project MUSE
data.text:
Marlin Barton's most recent book of fiction is The Cross Garden, a novel.

Ann E. Berthoff has written essays and reviewed for this magazine since 1963.

William E. Cain holds a chair in English at Wellesley College. He is coeditor of the Norton Anthology of Literary Theory and Criticism (2nd ed., 2010).

John W. Crowley, now retired, taught American literature for forty years, during which time he published widely.

William E. Engel's most recent book is devoted to Melville's and Poe's debts to early modern aesthetics, and he is currently coediting an anthology of imagery and texts on the Renaissance arts of memory.

Ernest J. Finney's third collection of short fiction, Sequoia Gardens, was published by the smu Press in 2011. Several of his stories have been anthologized; and he has published four novels.

Rebecca Foust published two books of poetry in 2010. She has poems in current issues of the Hudson Review, the North American Review, and Arts & Letters.

Russell Fraser is Austin Warren professor of English, emeritus, at the University of Michigan. He has published books on travel, on poets in English, and biographies, including Shakespeare's life.

Brendan Galvin earned the Aiken Taylor Prize in Modern American Poetry. He is widely published in many periodicals and has written several books of poetry.

David Heddendorf is an independent scholar and critic working in Ames, Iowa. His essays and reviews regularly appear in these pages.

Nancy Revelle Johnson, a historian with a special interest in women's lives and history, has reviewed memoirs for this quarterly for many years.

John Kinsella's most recent volume of poetry was published by Norton in 2011. He is a fellow at Churchill College, Cambridge, and of the University of Western Australia.

Robert Lacy, a frequent contributor of essays and reviews to the SR for over a decade, also writes for the Antioch Review and various other magazines.

Mel Livatino's essays have appeared in various periodicals; this is his fourth essay in the SR.

Jayanta Mahapatra's first book of poetry, A Rain of Rites, was published in 1976 by the University of Georgia Press. Since then he has published over a dozen books.

David Mason's latest book is The Scarlet Libretto, words for Laurie Laitman's opera based on Hawthorne's great novel. "Sea Salt: Poems of a Decade" will appear early next year.

Merritt Moseley has been reporting on the Booker Prize for the SR for many years. His scholarly interests include the great Victorians.

Kent Nelson's first published story appeared in the SR in 1974. He has seen 755 North American bird species and run the Pikes Peak marathon twice.

Sanford Pinsker, professor of humanities, emeritus, at Franklin and Marshall College, continues to write many essays and reviews for a variety of magazines, especially the Sewanee Review.

F. D. Reeve, a man of letters who was well known as a translator, fiction writer, and poet, wrote for this magazine since 1982.

Richard Stern, was a professor at the University of Chicago, wrote in many modes, especially short fiction. His last collection of stories was reviewed in these pages by Bruce Allen.

Donald Stone is currently senior professor in the English department at Peking University, professor emeritus at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, and the author of many books.

Cushing Strout's vocation is American intellectual history; his avocation, English detective fiction.

Kathleen Tarr's work has appeared in TriQuarterly, Creative Nonfiction, American Magazine, and other periodicals.

Philip Weinstein is Cummins Professor of English at Swarthmore College. He has written six books, all of which focus on nineteenth- and twentieth-century fiction.

James L. W. West III is completing his edition of Fitzgerald's fiction. In April he was awarded the Woods prize for distinction as a prose stylist by the Fellowship of Southern Writers. [End Page lxvii]
